title: 109_hr1862
content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires mandatory drug testing for athletes in professional sports associations such as Major League Baseball, the National Basketball Association, the National Football League, and others as determined by the Secretary of Commerce. The Secretary must issue regulations within 270 days of the Act's enactment, mandating professional sports associations to conduct random drug testing on athletes for performance-enhancing substances at least once a year. The substances to be tested for will be determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency and the Secretary. The Act mandates random drug testing on athletes for performance-enhancing substances determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency and the Secretary. Tests must be conducted by an independent party, and positive results lead to suspension from the professional sports association for a minimum of 2 years, with permanent suspension for repeat offenders. An athlete who tests positive for performance-enhancing substances will be permanently suspended from the professional sports association, with a loss of pay during the suspension. The athlete's name will be disclosed to the public, and they have the right to appeal within 5 days. The appeal process must be completed within 30 days, and penalties are stayed pending the appeal outcome. SEC. 4. EXEMPTIONS.

The Secretary may exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations from compliance.

SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

Starting 1 year after final rules are issued, the Secretary can fine associations not following regulations, with an initial fine of $5,000,000 and daily increases.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must report on the effectiveness of regulations every 2 years to Congress. Additionally, a study on performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes will be conducted by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General will assess testing policies in detecting performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes and make recommendations to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment.
